title: 110_hr6512
content: The Act is titled the "Major Regulation Cost Review Act of 2008" and requires periodic review of all major rules. The Major Regulation Cost Review Act of 2008 mandates agencies to conduct periodic reviews of major rules to determine if they should be continued, amended, or rescinded. The review must be done within five years of the rule's effective date. The Major Regulation Cost Review Act of 2008 requires agencies to review all existing major rules within five years of the effective date and new rules within five years of publication. Factors considered include the need for the rule, public feedback, and complexity. The Major Regulation Cost Review Act of 2008 mandates agencies to review all major rules within five years of enactment, considering factors like rule complexity, overlap with other rules, and changes in technology or economic conditions. The review must include a cost-benefit analysis following the methodology in Office of Management and Budget Circular A-4. Each year, agencies must publish a list of major rules to be reviewed in the Federal Register, inviting public comment. The term 'major rule' is defined as provided by section 804 of this title. Title 5, United States Code, amended to include a new item after section 610. SEC. 3. REQUIREMENTS FOR OMB RELATING TO ANNUAL ACCOUNTING STATEMENT. Periodic review of major rules. The amendment requires including a list of rules to be reviewed annually in the accounting statement and using agency cost-benefit estimates in the statement. The amendment mandates agencies to submit annual cost-benefit analyses for major rules to the Office of Management and Budget.
